name: Rome
intro_vibe: The Eternal City: A chaotic open-air museum where ancient ruins meet Vespa traffic and perfect pasta.

general_info.description: Rome runs on ritual, not efficiency. It is a collision of 3,000 years of history, gritty street life, and strict food rules. Don't rush; meals are sacred blocks of time. It is noisy, messy, and stunningly beautiful. Accept the chaos; it is part of the charm.

etiquette_tips: No Cappuccino After 11am: Milk is for breakfast. Ordering a cappuccino after lunch is a digestive crime. Order 'caffè' (espresso) or 'caffè macchiato'.
The Bill Ritual: The check will rarely come automatically. You must catch the waiter's eye and mime scribbling. Paying at the table vs. the cashier varies; watch what locals do.
Time is Fluid (Except for Food): Trains might be late, shops might close randomly, but meal times are rigid. Lunch is 1-3pm. Dinner is 8:30pm+. Don't try to eat dinner at 6pm.
Dress Code: Shoulders and knees MUST be covered for St. Peter's/Pantheon. In general, Romans dress well. Athletic wear in the city center marks you as a tourist.
Chaos Mindset: Lines are suggestions. Interruptions are normal. Arguing about efficiency is futile. Rome runs on social flow, not systems. Relax and go with it.
Ticket Validation: Validate bus/tram tickets in the yellow machines. Inspectors are ruthless and target tourists.
Water Fountains (Nasoni): The street water fountains flow constantly with cold, clean volcanic water. Drink from them! Carry a reusable bottle.

neighborhoods.name: Trastevere
neighborhoods.description: Ivy-covered buildings, cobblestone streets, and intense nightlife. Beautiful by day, a street party by night. It gets very crowded, but the charm is undeniable.

neighborhoods.name: Monti
neighborhoods.description: Rome's hipster village right next to the Colosseum. Vintage shops, wine bars, and artisans. Where locals hang out to avoid the tourist crush.

neighborhoods.name: Testaccio
neighborhoods.description: The gritty heart of Roman cuisine. Home to the old slaughterhouse and the best traditional trattorias. Not pretty, but tasty and authentic.

neighborhoods.name: Centro Storico
neighborhoods.description: The heart of Baroque Rome. Pantheon, Navona, Trevi. Stunning, crowded, and expensive. Visit early morning or late night.

logistics.title: Local Survival Tips
details: Coffee Bar Rule: Price is regulated at the bar (~€1.10), but doubles if you sit at a table. Drink standing up like a local.
The Coperto: Restaurants add a €2-3 'cover charge' per person for bread/table. This is normal. Tipping is NOT required.
August Shutdown: The city empties in mid-August. Many authentic restaurants close for 2 weeks. Tourist traps stay open.
Heat Survival: In summer, locals avoid walking between 1pm-4pm. Shade-hopping is a survival skill.

logistics.title: Getting Around
logistics.summary: Walk whenever possible. Public transit is notoriously unreliable.
details: Walking: The historic center is compact. It is the best way to see the city. Wear comfortable shoes; cobblestones are unforgiving.
Metro: Only 3 lines (A, B, C). Useful for getting across town (e.g. Vatican to Termini), but useless for the center.
Taxi: Do not hail on the street (they won't stop). Go to a Taxi Rank or use the 'FreeNow' app. Uber is available but expensive.

logistics.title: Safety & Scams
details: Pickpocket Routes: Be hyper-vigilant on Bus 64 (Vatican bus), crowded Metro A, and queues for the Colosseum.
The Bracelet Scam: Men will try to tie a 'free' bracelet on your wrist then demand money. Keep hands in pockets.
Termini Station: The area around the main train station is gritty at night. Stay on main streets.

must_eat.description: Rome's holy dish. Egg yolks, Pecorino Romano cheese, Guanciale (cured pork cheek), and black pepper. NO cream. Cream is a crime here.

Know where to eat. A good Trattoria looks boring, is loud, and has paper tablecloths. Avoid places with photos on the menu, a 'Tourist Menu', or a host outside inviting you in. Authentic places don't need to beg.
Fried food is a religion here. Before pizza or pasta, you order 'Fritti'. Includes Supplì, potato croquettes, and fried zucchini flowers (Fiori di Zucca). Eaten with hands, shared, and essential.
Rome has the oldest Jewish community in Europe. Their cuisine is legendary, especially 'Carciofi alla Giudia' (deep-fried whole artichokes). Simple, oil-heavy, and crispy.
Wine is food here. 'Vino della Casa' is cheap, served in a carafe, and perfectly acceptable. You don't need to order a bottle. It is drunk casually at lunch and dinner.
Pasta with Pecorino cheese and black pepper. Simple ingredients, incredibly hard to master. Creamy, spicy, salty perfection.
Tomato, Guanciale, Pecorino, and chili. The spicy, red cousin of Carbonara. Rich, savory, and essential.
Rectangular pizza sold by weight. Point to the one you want, show them how much with your hands. It is the standard Roman fast lunch.
Fried rice ball stuffed with ragù and mozzarella. Rome's favorite street snack. Break it open to see the 'telephone wire' of cheese.
Sweet breakfast bun filled with an insane amount of fresh whipped cream. Messy and delicious. Get it at Regoli.
Slow-roasted pork heavily seasoned with herbs and garlic. Served in crusty bread. The ultimate street food lunch.

items.description: Markets (like Testaccio or Campo de' Fiori) are morning-only affairs. They are loud, functional, and where real food shopping happens. Go for the atmosphere and a fresh fruit snack.
Rome transforms after dark. The ruins are lit up, the air cools down, and the piazzas fill with locals. Walking the center at midnight is safer, quieter, and more magical than at noon.
The world's largest amphitheater. Book tickets WEEKS in advance. The underground tour is worth it.
The best-preserved building from ancient Rome. The dome is an engineering miracle. Entry is now paid, book online.
A church, but actually a free art museum. Contains three stunning Caravaggio masterpieces. Bring coins to light up the paintings.
The most romantic sunset view in Rome. Overlooks the river and St. Peter's dome. Quiet and scented with orange trees.
The highest hill in Rome (not one of the 7). Sweeping panoramic views. A canon is fired daily at noon.
The center of the Catholic world. Massive, opulent, and free. Go at 7am to avoid the 2-hour line.
Home to the Sistine Chapel. It is incredibly crowded. Book the 'Early Morning' tour or prepare to be crushed.

affiliate_products.reason: Italy has a unique 3-pin plug (Type L) alongside the standard Euro plug. Essential for charging.

affiliate_products.title: Anti-Theft Crossbody Bag
affiliate_products.reason: Pickpockets on buses and metros are skilled. A locking bag gives you peace of mind.

affiliate_products.title: Reusable Water Bottle
affiliate_products.reason: Rome has thousands of free, cold water fountains (nasoni). Refill yours for free all day.
